body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Download the MSI for v7.2.2 and run it.
   a. Use a custom directory (in my case I choose `D:\PowerShell`)
   b. Untick the options to update automatically through Windows Update or WSUS.
2. Now download the MSI for v7.2.3 and run it.
3. When you reach the page for the installation directory, it shows the default directory in `C:\Program Files`.
4. When you reach the page for automatic updates, both options are ticked.

### Expected behavior

The installer for a new version should respect the options that were selected for the previous verison.

### Actual behavior

The installer for a new version uses the default options.


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Related Issues

This could be related to #17211, which is about the original installation directory not being respected when PowerShell is automatically updated through Windows Update.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

- Download Powershell v7.2.1 x64 MSI installer
- Install Powershell into an internal secondary drive
- Make sure to enable MU features in the installer
- Run Windows Update
- Windows Update should start downloading and installing Powershell v7.2.2
- After Update notice how the Powershell install folder on the secondary drive is empty and Powershell is now installed on your main drive.

### Expected behavior

```console
Windows Update should update Powershell 7 to the original directory you installed it in.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Windows Update has no regard for where you would like programs installed and instead chooses to install Powershell 7 updates on the main drive.
```

### Steps to reproduce

@theJasonHelmick Per our conversation at the PS conference, please see the issue details below. Thanks for taking an interest!

I'm running get user against the Graph web API using `invoke-restmethod.` In production, I would pull multiple users, so I was testing performance potential with `foreach-object -parallel` over my current `foreach ($i in $is) {}`. The iterated call using `-parallel` errored with _'CompactToken parsing failed with error code: 80049217.'_ To make sure I didn't have a stale token or syntax issue, I ran the same code without the -parallel switch The calls were successful. If I place the token string directly into the code when using '-parallel' the calls are also successful. All three scenarios are shown in screenshots below.

In our discussion, I mentioned I thought it was related to wrapping my token variable in '$()' but I've tried it the code just passing the variable directly without the wrap with the same results. It was a red herring with from extranious code. :)

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When looking at the help documentation for `Invoke-Command`, one of the valid parameter sets suggests that the only mandatory parameter is `-Credential`.

```plaintext
Invoke-Command
      -Credential <PSCredential>
      [-ConfigurationName <String>]
      [-ThrottleLimit <Int32>]
      [-AsJob]
      [-HideComputerName]
      [-ScriptBlock] <ScriptBlock>
      [-RemoteDebug]
      [-InputObject <PSObject>]
      [-ArgumentList <Object[]>]
      [-VMId] <Guid[]>
      [<CommonParameters>]
```

This means that the following command would be a valid way to run a specified `-ScriptBlock` with a provided credential.

```powershell
Invoke-Command -Credential $Cred -ScriptBlock { 'Hello world' }
```

But it results in an error saying it's an invalid combination of parameters.

```plaintext
Invoke-Command: Parameter set cannot be resolved using the specified named parameters. One or more parameters issued cannot be used together or an insufficient number of parameters were provided.
```

I've tried both newer PowerShell versions as well as Windows PowerShell, and since the problem exists in several versions of the documentation I suspect it's an old bug.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> $Cred = [pscredential]::new('test', ('123' | ConvertTo-SecureString -AsPlainText))
PS> Invoke-Command -Credential $Cred -ScriptBlock { 'Hello world' }
Hello world
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> $Cred = [pscredential]::new('test', ('123' | ConvertTo-SecureString -AsPlainText))
PS> Invoke-Command -Credential $Cred -ScriptBlock { 'Hello world' }
Invoke-Command: Parameter set cannot be resolved using the specified named parameters. One or more parameters issued cannot be used together or an insufficient number of parameters were provided.
```

body:
### Steps to reproduce

Test-Connection with the -quiet parameter is performing inversely to what the microsoft documents state it will. The description of -quiet states "If any ping to a given target succeeds, $True is returned. If all pings to a given target fail, $False is returned." I can confirm this works as described in Powershell 5.1, but in 7+ it appears to work inversely. If any of the the replies are fail then the bool returns $false. I have tested it several times and it has always reproduced the same results. Thank you in advance for your assistance everyone. 

Documentation for the Test-Connection commandlet. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.management/test-connection?view=powershell-7.2#:~:text=False-,%2DQuiet,-The%20Quiet%20parameter

```console
#This assumes at least 1 reply.
```

body:
# PR Summary

PowerShell fail to build even when the correct .NET SDK version is installed.

## PR Context

There are two issues with how the .NET SDK version check works,

1. The regex parsing fail on certain versions due to unescaped dots. 
2. When the supported SDK isn't the last entry in the generated list of installed SDK's it fails.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Passing a bareword argument to a parameter that isn't type-constrained is parsed as a number if it looks like one.

The resulting value self-identifies _as a number_ and _mostly_ acts as such, but it is wrapped in an invisible `[psobject]` instance in which the original string representation is cached.

In the context of `-f`, this string representation surfaces unexpectedly, meaning that the value is unexpectedly not treated as a number:

```powershell
& { param($p) $p.GetType().FullName; '{0:N2}' -f $p } 0x1a
```


### Expected behavior

```console
System.Int32
26.00
```


### Actual behavior

```console
System.Int32
0x1a
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.3
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: The reported behavior is by design.
labels.name: Resolution-By Design

including the space at the end, with cases the the semantic version constructor to throw a terminating error, halting the build.

Also improving error diagnostics for when this happens.

title: Fixing dotnet sdk version parsing in build.psm1

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Calling e.g. 'Remove-Item' on a path longer than MAX_PATH will result in the following error,
`Remove-Item: The system cannot find the path specified.`
This works as expected in the PowerShell 5.1 version. 
Specifically, the `longPathAware` setting is missing from the manifest. Doing a simple Hex find in the executable reveals this while being there in the older PowerShell version.

Suggested fix is to add the following to the manifest (from [Microsoft](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/maximum-file-path-limitation?tabs=cmd)):
`
<application xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v3">
    <windowsSettings xmlns:ws2="http://schemas.microsoft.com/SMI/2016/WindowsSettings">
        <ws2:longPathAware>true</ws2:longPathAware>
    </windowsSettings>
</application>
`


### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Remove-Item <SOME_MAX_PATH_EXCEEDING_PATH>
PS>
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Remove-Item <SOME_MAX_PATH_EXCEEDING_PATH>
Remove-Item: The system cannot find the path specified.
```


### Error details

```console
PS> get-error
```

title: Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK: Custom script parameters are not fully serialized, when invoked via remote session

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

`cd` into `C:\` and use `Resolve-Path "C:"`, then `cd` into `C:\Windows` and use `Resolve-Path "C:"`.
It should output `C:\` both times, but in the second case it will output `C:\Windows`.
This is neither specific to the windows folder nor to the C:\ drive.
When omitting the backslash and only passing the driveletter and colon to `Resolve-Path`, the current path will be outputted instead of the drive letter

### Expected behavior

```console
PS C:\> Resolve-Path "C:"
C:\
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS C:\Windows> Resolve-Path "C:"
C:\Windows
```

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

Adds `ValidateNotNullOrWhiteSpace` to `System.Management.Automation`

## PR Context

Closes #10010

Currently, users who want to validate a string or collection of strings will add the `[ValidateNotNullOrEmpty()]` attribute to it and then manually validate the string with `[String]::IsNullOrWhiteSpace(my_string)`.

```powershell
[ValidateNotNullOrEmpty()]
[String[]]
$string_collection = @("a", "b", " ", "d")

foreach ($str in $string_collection)
{
    if (-not [String]::IsNullOrWhiteSpace($str))
    {
        throw [System.ArgumentNullException] "Element consisted entirely of white-space characters"
    }
}
```

Alternate implentation @vexx32 suggested could have been a bool argument to ValidateNotNullOrEmpy: `ValidateNotNullOrEmpty(WhiteSpace)`. However I have chosen to implement this as a seperate attribute as users who work with strings know to use a seperate attribute when validating them: `ValidateNotNullOrEmpty` as opposed to `ValidateNotNull`. `ValidateNotNullOrEmpty` adds a further requirement for the validation over `ValidateNotNull`. Likewise `ValidateNotNullOrWhiteSpace` adds the further requirement of no strings consisting entirely of white-space over `ValidateNotNullOrEmpty`. 

Also, this is my first commit 😊

### Class Diagram Before
```mermaid
classDiagram
    ValidateArgumentsAttribute <|-- NullValidationAttributeBase
    NullValidationAttributeBase <|-- ValidateNotNullAttribute
    NullValidationAttributeBase <|-- ValidateNotNullOrEmptyAttribute
    class ValidateArgumentsAttribute {
        <<abstract>>
        #Validate(object arguments, EngineIntrinsics engineIntrinsics)* void
    }
    class NullValidationAttributeBase {
        <<abstract>>
        #IsArgumentCollection(Type argumentType, out bool isElementValueType) bool
    }
    class ValidateNotNullAttribute{
        #Validate(object arguments, EngineIntrinsics engineIntrinsics) void
    }
    class ValidateNotNullOrEmptyAttribute{
        #Validate(object arguments, EngineIntrinsics engineIntrinsics) void
    }
```
### Class Diagram After
```mermaid
classDiagram
    ValidateArgumentsAttribute <|-- NullValidationAttributeBase
    NullValidationAttributeBase <|-- ValidateNotNullAttribute
    NullValidationAttributeBase <|-- ValidateNotNullOr
    ValidateNotNullOr <|-- ValidateNotNullOrEmptyAttribute
    ValidateNotNullOr <|-- ValidateNotNullOrWhiteSpaceAttribute
    class ValidateArgumentsAttribute {
        <<abstract>>
        #Validate(object arguments, EngineIntrinsics engineIntrinsics)* void
    }
    class NullValidationAttributeBase {
        <<abstract>>
        #IsArgumentCollection(Type argumentType, out bool isElementValueType) bool
    }
    class ValidateNotNullAttribute{
        #Validate(object arguments, EngineIntrinsics engineIntrinsics) void
    }
    class ValidateNotNullOr{
        <<abstract>>
        #bool _whiteSpace
        #ValidateNotNullOr(bool whiteSpace)*
        #Validate(object arguments, EngineIntrinsics engineIntrinsics) void
    }
    class ValidateNotNullOrEmptyAttribute {
        +ValidateNotNullOrEmptyAttribute(bool whiteSpace)
    }
    class ValidateNotNullOrWhiteSpaceAttribute {
        +ValidateNotNullOrWhiteSpaceAttribute(bool whiteSpace)
    }
```
## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes
- [x] [Summarized changes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
- [x] [Make sure all `.h`, `.cpp`, `.cs`, `.ps1` and `.psm1` files have the correct copyright header](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
- [x] This PR is ready to merge and is not [Work in Progress](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---work-in-progress).
    - If the PR is work in progress, please add the prefix `WIP:` or `[ WIP ]` to the beginning of the title (the `WIP` bot will keep its status check at `Pending` while the prefix is present) and remove the prefix when the PR is ready.
- **[Breaking changes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#making-breaking-changes)**

body:
This corrects an issue where the movement of objects in the array to be sorted where removing duplicate elements may result in a side effect of objects being out of order for a unique stable sort as seen in issue #16907.  

This can be reproduced with the below code
```powershell
$Record1=[PSCustomObject]@{Key="A";Record="A1"}
$Record2=[PSCustomObject]@{Key="A";Record="A2"}
$Record3=[PSCustomObject]@{Key="B";Record="B1"}
$Record4=[PSCustomObject]@{Key="B";Record="B2"}
$Records = @($Record1,$Record2,$Record3,$Record4)
$results = $Records | Sort-Object -Stable -Unique -Property Key
$results  | Format-Table
```

This results in 
```
Key Record
--- ------
A   A1
B   B2
```

Where the expected results is.
```
Key Record
--- ------
A   A1
B   B1
```

This problem occurs when a duplicate element in the array is found and then replaced with an element from the end.  In the example above causing record B2 to be put in place of A2.  After that, record B2 is treated as the first object for the unique selection despite the stable flag being set to retain the order.

### Steps to reproduce

Binding full file-system item paths to `Select-String`'s `-LiteralPath` parameter (via its alias name, `-PSPath`) based in input objects' `.PSPath` property values works via provider-decorated `System.IO.FileInfo` instances, such as `Get-ChildItem`, but not with `[pscustomobject]` instances, for example:

```powershell
'zzz' > ($tmpFile = New-TemporaryFile) # Create temp. file with sample content.

$o = [pscustomobject] @{ PSPath = $tmpFile.FullName }

# OK: Get-Content binds the .PSPath property to -LiteralPath, as expected.
$o | Get-Content

# !! BROKEN: Select-String doesn't bind to -LiteralPath and instead searches the
# !!                  stringified object.
$o | Select-String .

Remove-Item $tmpFile # cleanup
```


### Expected behavior

```console
zzz

/path/to/tmpfile.tmp:1:zzz
```

### Actual behavior

```console
zzz

@{PSPath=/path/to/tmpfile.tmp}
```

That is, `Select-String` unexpectedly searched the `.ToString()` representation of the input object that was bound to `-InputObject`.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.3
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

We all know the code constructs like this:
```Powershell
$Temp = $ErrorActionPreference
$ErrorActionPreference = "stop"
(Doing Stuff)
$ErrorActionPreference = $Temp
```
With any of the many available preference variables. When "Doing Stuff" is only calling one cmdlet, this can easily be simplified using the `-ErrorAction "silentlycontinue"` parameter, but when you need to set it for multiple calls and some in-between lines of code, that can get very annoying and confusing.

When working with locations, you could use `Push-Location` and `Pop-Location` to make your code very concise and easy to read. Something similar for preference variables would simplify code snippets like the example above a lot.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Since preference variables are mutable enums, I don't think for example `$ErrorActionPreference.Push("stop")` would work, instead cmdlets like `Push-ErrorActionPreference "stop"` similar to locations would need to be made.

Also some thought would need to be put into how this would work in conjunction with the common parameter `-ErrorAction`, for example that every time the parameter is explicitly specified, it gets pushed, and on end of the cmdlet, it is popped.

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

    try {
            ([System.Security.Principal.WindowsPrincipal][System.Security.Principal.WindowsIdentity]::GetCurrent()
            ).IsInRole([System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole]::Administrator)    

    } catch {
        throw "Failed to determine if the current user has elevated privileges. The error was: '{0}'." -f $_
    }
    <#
        .SYNOPSIS
            Checks if the current Powershell instance is running with elevated privileges or not.
        .EXAMPLE
            PS C:\> Test-IsAdmin
        .OUTPUTS
            System.Boolean
                True if the current Powershell is elevated, false if not.
    #>
}

Put in  $PROFILE.CurrentUserAllHosts :
  & $profile.AllUsersAllHost


### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Test-IsAdmin -eq Test-IsAdmin
True
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Test-IsAdmin -eq Test-IsAdmin
False
PS> Test-IsAdmin -eq ($(Test-IsAdmin))
False
PS>Test-IsAdmin -eq $(Test-IsAdmin)
False

But:

PS> $(Test-IsAdmin) -eq $(Test-IsAdmin)
True
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. creating a PSCmdlet, even just an "hello world!" like, but writing the VT100 escape code to query the device (`\x1B[0c`) 
2. reading the terminal response from the Escape code.
3. writing a test for it (optionally assigning the output to `TestContext`)
4. this will trigger `'Host.UI.RawUI.KeyAvailable' threw an exception of type 'System.Management.Automation.Host.HostException'`


### Expected behavior

```console
In this case there is no user input involved, but it is just a check if a key has been pressed. (Ok, implicitly can be considered that a user pressed a key, but this is not true anymore with escape codes)

Also on following on that, the `ReadKey` method won't be available if wants to interoperate with EscapeCodes. (when those are not supported won't read anything)

---

It is expected to have at least an alternative method that doesn't throw if called, but can allow the normal execution of that code path, without wrapping it in a `try/catch` block.

for this specific case, when query the device with escape codes, worst case there won't be any response.
but there won't be an exception neither.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
In the context of running test (automation) even just to check if a key has been pressed, in this case could be a response for the VT100 not a user, instead throws like if it is supposed to ask user input.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
.
```

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

Tested on Windows 10/11 with PS 7.2 and 5.1 with the default PS terminal, "Terminal" and VSCode.
Set your keyboard to a language that don't have the Latin alphabet, for example add Hebrew keyboard in the windows settings in addition to the English one.
1. Start PowerShell.
2. Set keyboard to the other language (like with `Alt + Shift` or in the taskbar).
3. Press `Ctrl + C` (or `Ctrl + <Any letter>`).
4. Terminal will print the letter (or something like � if the font doesn't have it) instead of the expected `^C`.
5. Even if you switch back to English and `Ctrl + C` it will still print the letter from the other language.

I didn't find a way to "fix" the session to make `Ctrl + C` work, only thing you can do is close it, open a new one and making sure the first  `Ctrl + C` you make is in English.


### Expected behavior
`^C` always executed no matter what is your current active keyboard or what keyboard was active when it was first typed. Like in CMD for example.
```console
PS C:\> ^C
PS C:\>
```


### Actual behavior
`Ctrl + C` become unusable for the rest of the session if when it first used the keyboard wasn't on English.
```console
PS C:\> ב
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Filtering PSCustomObjects with multiple 'not equal' operators returns fewer results than expected. For example, consider the following sample code.

An object is created with multiple PSCustomObjects added containing the first and last names of users:
```powershell
$OldFile = @()

$OldFile += [PSCustomObject]@{firstName = 'Peter'; lastName = 'Hall'}

$OldFile += [PSCustomObject]@{firstName = 'Peter'; lastName = 'Griffin'}

$OldFile += [PSCustomObject]@{firstName = 'Peter'; lastName = 'Greenwood'}

$OldFile += [PSCustomObject]@{firstName = 'Jane'; lastName = 'Greenwood'} 

$OldFile += [PSCustomObject]@{firstName = 'John'; lastName = 'Greenwood'}

$OldFile += [PSCustomObject]@{firstName = 'James'; lastName = 'Greenwood'}

$OldFile


firstName lastName
--------- --------
Peter     Hall
Peter     Griffin
Peter     Greenwood
Jane      Greenwood
John      Greenwood
James     Greenwood
```

Filtering the object to exclude users with a first name of 'Peter' and last name of 'Hall' incorrectly excludes Peter Griffin and Peter Greenwood too:
```powershell
$OldFile | Where-Object {$_.firstName -ne 'Peter' -and $_.lastName -ne 'Hall'}


firstName lastName
--------- --------
Jane      Greenwood
John      Greenwood
James     Greenwood
```

If this is the intended behaviour, reversing the logic should see Peter Hall, Peter Griffin, and Peter Greenwood included in the results, but this is not the case:
```powershell
$OldFile | Where-Object {$_.firstName -eq 'Peter' -and $_.lastName -eq 'Hall'}


firstName lastName
--------- --------
Peter     Hall
```

### Expected behavior

```console
$OldFile | Where-Object {$_.firstName -ne 'Peter' -and $_.lastName -ne 'Hall'}


firstName lastName
--------- --------
Peter     Griffin
Peter     Greenwood
Jane      Greenwood
John      Greenwood
James     Greenwood

# Peter Griffin and Peter Greenwood are correctly included in the results.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
$OldFile | Where-Object {$_.firstName -ne 'Peter' -and $_.lastName -ne 'Hall'}


firstName lastName
--------- --------
Jane      Greenwood
John      Greenwood
James     Greenwood

# Peter Griffin and Peter Greenwood are incorrectly excluded from the results.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
$PSVersionTable                                                       


Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.2
OS                             Darwin 21.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 21.4.0: Fri Mar 18 00:46:32 PDT 2022; root:x…
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

PowerShell now expands the globs when using native commands on Linux. This is very inconvenient to me for a few reasons:

- I use PowerShell on both Linux and Windows, and I have to always be cautious so that I don't make mistakes. (I can use `git checkout master -- *` on Windows, but I have to quote the `*` on Linux. It was really scary when I once ran `yarn up **` on Linux...)
- When working with `bash`, I know that it will always expand the globs I use. When working with PowerShell on Windows, I know that it will never do that. But on Linux, it has an inconsistent behavior that I have to think about before running commands. (This gets worse when the same command can mean different things on Windows and Linux, like `rm` and `ls` and the likes.)
- PowerShell glob expansion still needs work (#15959 and #13098 for example), and I don't want to get caught in the middle of my work.
- I don't like glob expansion in bash anyways. It is a somewhat scary feature to me. (I almost always quote my wildcards in bash, if the command I'm using recognizes them (like `git`), or switch to PowerShell if it doesn't.)

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Add a configuration to PowerShell to disable glob expansion on Linux, or if such configuration already exists, include a mention to it in the docs ([here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/whats-new/unix-support) for example).

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Note: This may not arise often in practice, but there are two concerns:

* The original behavior is surprising.
* _Repeating_ the command - for an already type-constrained variable - _changes_ the behavior.

```powershell
Remove-Variable -ErrorAction Ignore var # Make sure no $var variable exists.

([bool] $var = 42).GetType().Name # !! 'Int32', i.e. the type of the input rather than the stored converted value.

# Repeating the command - even with a different constraining type - then *does* return the converted value.
# NB: The symptom only surfaces with the same variable, i.e. with a *previously type-constrained* one.
([string] $var = 42).GetType().Name # !! 'String'
```


### Expected behavior

```console
Boolean
String
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Int32
String
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.3
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Using `Get-ChildItem`, can anyone advise whether it's possible to non-recursively list files where the directory is specified as a LiteralPath and the filename(s) returned must match a given string containing wildcards?

This is the closest I've managed to get:

```powershell
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath "C:\Bitbucket\Test\foo[1-5]bar" -Filter "*.doc" -File
```

The `-Filter` parameter uses the FileSystem provider rather than PowerShell wildcards _(`Get-Help about_Wildcard`)_. PowerShell wildcards are well understood and it's unlikely that the syntax will ever change dramatically (or at least not in a breaking change way). Whereas, when relying on the FileSystem provider for filtering, although there are many similarities to PowerShell wildcards, PowerShell has no influence over its behaviour, you are completely at the mercy of .Net Core and this makes me feel it's a potentially risky proposition to use.

_(The behaviour of `-Filter` has changed dramatically between Windows PowerShell and Powershell Core. To illustrate this, in Windows PowerShell if `C:\Bitbucket\Test\foo[1-5]bar` contained both `.doc` and `.docx` files then `Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath "C:\Bitbucket\Test\foo[1-5]bar" -Filter "*.doc" -File` would return files with both extensions, whereas this is not the case in PowerShell Core)_ 

Here are a couple of workarounds I've come up with... I'm not entirely sure if I'd trust the second option just in case there are any quirks or edge cases that I've failed to consider.

```powershell
################################################################################
# WORKAROUND 1
# Delegate responsibility for filtering to the Where method.
(Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath "C:\Bitbucket\Test\foo[1-5]bar" -File).Where({$_.name -like "*.doc"})
################################################################################
# WORKAROUND 2
# Use Get-ChildItem with a non-literal path to take advantage of PowerShell's
# wildcard filtering but before doing so, check that the directory path 
# "literally" exists, the filename is a value that can only be interpreted as a 
# file (not a directory) by ensuring that it does NOT contain any path 
# separators ("\" or "/") and then escape the directory path.
$DirectoryPath = "C:\Bitbucket\Test\foo[1-5]bar"
$Filename = "*.doc"

If (Test-Path -LiteralPath $DirectoryPath -Type Container) {
    If (!($Filename.ToCharArray().Where({ ('\', '/').contains([string]$_.ToString()) }))) {
        $DirectoryPathEscaped = [Management.Automation.WildcardPattern]::Escape($DirectoryPath)
        Get-ChildItem -Path "$DirectoryPathEscaped\$Filename" -File
    }
}
################################################################################
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

I'd be delighted if someone could tell me of a way to achieve the result I want using nothing but `Get-ChildItem`, however if that's simply not possible at present then I'd like to ask the PowerShell team and the community to consider whether it would be feasible and desirable to add new functionality that (somehow) enables a user to modify the behaviour of `-Filter` so that it can 
operate using PowerShell wildcard filtering?

Can anyone comment on whether the implementation of such a feature would theoretically offer performance benefits over using the `Where` method _(as shown in 'workaround 1')_ to perform filtering?

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.description: The issue is new and needs to be triaged by a work group.
labels.name: Needs-Triage

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Powershell process is Killed when CTRL-C from Script or any program.
__OCCURS WITH POWERSHELL CORE v7.2.1 and latest preview 7.3.0__ 

When I do CTRL-C on a running script, I don't exit back to prompt. It kills powershell (pwsh.exe). Same goes for any random program.



### Expected behavior

```console
ᶜᵒʳᵉ⁷> For($i = 1 ; ; $i++){ Write-Host $i ; Sleep -Seconds 1 }
1
2
3
# user ctrl-c
ᶜᵒʳᵉ⁷>
```


### Actual behavior

```console
ᶜᵒʳᵉ⁷> For($i = 1 ; ; $i++){ Write-Host $i ; Sleep -Seconds 1 }
1
2
3
# user ctrl-c (kills shell)
[process exited with code 4294967295]
```


### Error details

```console
process exited with code 4294967295
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

media
- [DEMO GIF](https://arsscriptum.github.io/assets/gif/demo1.gif)
- [Question Image](https://arsscriptum.github.io/files/question.png)

### Prerequisites - [X] Write a descriptive title. - [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages/PSReadLine) - [X] Search the existing issues, especially the pinned issues. ### Exception report ```console N/A ``` ### Screenshot ![Get-PSReadLineOption 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57874058/163656257-6a189271-478c-40f1-97ac-752d74ed160b.png) ![Get-PSReadLineOption 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57874058/163656260-27d8cba6-3390-4795-9c7d-273b2fb9d269.png) ### Environment data ```console PS Version: 5.1.19041.1645 PS HostName: ConsoleHost PSReadLine Version: 2.2.2 PSReadLine EditMode: Windows OS: 10.0.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800) BufferWidth: 106 BufferHeight: 3000 ``` ### Steps to reproduce Happens on PS 5.1 console and Windows Terminal app (cannot reproduce with the ISE nor PowerShell 7.2.2)
**To reproduce:** 1. Type `Get-PSReadlineOption | Format-List *`
**To resolve:** 1. Type `Get-PSReadLineOption` (without `| Format-List *`) and color scheme is restored after the property `CommandColor` is listed on-screen. See bottom screenshot for a better explanation of this. ### Expected behavior Color scheme should remain constant ### Actual behavior - Console color scheme now appears like the `ListPredictionSelectedColor` color scheme - Missing property values (see screenshot) - Clearing the screen/changing console size doesn't resolve the issue.

### Steps to reproduce

On Amazon EC2 linux:
```
sudo yum install -y powershell gssntlmssp
sudo pwsh -Command 'Install-Module -Name PSWSMan'
sudo pwsh -Command 'Install-WSMan'
```

On Windows instance:
Set up remote powershell access and open ports 5985-5986.

Create a file which is over 284715 bytes and pwsh to run commands:

```
dd if=/dev/zero of=./test count=1 bs=284716
pwsh
PS> $pass = ConvertTo-SecureString "MyPassword" -AsPlainText -Force
PS> $cred = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential ("SERVERNAME\Administrator", $pass)
PS> $ses = New-PSSession -ComputerName myserver.company.com -Credential $cred
PS> Copy-Item "./test" -Destination "C:\inetpub\Website\" -ToSession $ses -Recurse -Force
```

```console
Copying progress indicator, no error.
```

body:
The check in `ForEach-Object -Parallel` for `ScriptBlock`s in `$using:` values currently doesn't check `PSObject`s. This was discovered in #17150

This if:

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/7cc9c874730e87b06dbe54d50e77c1c472996c54/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/InternalCommands.cs#L422-L431

Might need to be:

```csharp
if (item is ScriptBlock or PSObject { BaseObject: ScriptBlock })
{
    // etc
}
```

### Steps to reproduce


```powershell
$sb = { 'worked' }
0 | ForEach-Object -Parallel { & $using:sb }

$sb = [psobject]{ 'worked' }
0 | ForEach-Object -Parallel { & $using:sb }
```



### Expected behavior

```console
ForEach-Object:
Line |
   2 |  0 | ForEach-Object -Parallel { & $using:sb }
     |      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | A ForEach-Object -Parallel using variable cannot be a script block. Passed-in script block variables are not supported with ForEach-Object -Parallel, and can result in undefined behavior.

ForEach-Object:
Line |
   5 |  0 | ForEach-Object -Parallel { & $using:sb }
     |      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | A ForEach-Object -Parallel using variable cannot be a script block. Passed-in script block variables are not supported with ForEach-Object -Parallel, and can result in undefined behavior.
```

### Actual behavior

```console
ForEach-Object:
Line |
   2 |  0 | ForEach-Object -Parallel { & $using:sb }
     |      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | A ForEach-Object -Parallel using variable cannot be a script block. Passed-in script block variables are not supported with ForEach-Object -Parallel, and can result in undefined behavior.
```

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

This was reported by a Windows partner.

`GetCurrentDirectory()` is a Win32 API that returns the current working directory.  This is used by native commands to resolve things like relative paths.  It will currently always return the directory where pwsh was started.

```powershell
cd $env:WINDIR
[System.IO.Directory]::GetCurrentDirectory()
```

PS7 should call `SetCurrentDirectory()` when the main console thread changes location and also set `$env:PWD`.  There are no guarantees for multi-threads as the current working directory is process scope.

### Expected behavior

```console
c:\Windows
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Your home dir
```

title: PowerShell doesn't call `SetCurrentDirectory()` when location changes nor sets `$env:PWD`

body: ### Issue I am not sure whether this actually qualifies as a security vulnerability (especially because it is apparently accepted as normal behavior) but I think it is not correct that by default (for Windows servers and where the Execution Policy is lowered) the profile between a standard user account and elevated administrator account is unnoticeable shared and invoked. ### [User Account Control](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/identity-protection/user-account-control/user-account-control-overview) > *User Account Control (UAC) helps prevent malware from damaging a PC and helps organizations deploy a better-managed desktop. With UAC, apps and tasks always run in the security context of a non-administrator account, unless an administrator specifically authorizes administrator-level access to the system. UAC can block the automatic installation of unauthorized apps and prevent inadvertent changes to system settings.* For Windows servers and where the Execution Policy is lowered, malware might easily copy itself to the user's profile (`$PROFILE.CurrentUserCurrentHost`) and proceed (unnoticed!) with elevated rights whenever the user starts PowerShell from the explorer '**Run as Administrator**' context menu. ### Expected behavior Foreign scripts should not be able to pass UAC and execute unseen by piggybacking on other domestic scripts as the `$Profile`. ### Actual behavior PowerShell is able to silently copy and invoke (possible malicious) code accepted by the *standard user* account in an *elevated administrator* account. ### Environment data ```powershell $PSVersionTable Name Value ---- ----- PSVersion 7.2.1 PSEdition Core GitCommitId 7.2.1 OS Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363 Platform Win32NT PSCompatibleVersions {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…} PSRemotingProtocolVersion 2.3 SerializationVersion 1.1.0.1 WSManStackVersion 3.0 ``` ### Propose As a practical workaround, I would recommend to restrict the Execution Policy when PowerShell is ran as administrator by setting the `$PROFILE.AllUsersAllHosts` as a standard (knowing administrators should be able to consciously change this). Basically (from an elevated prompt): ```PowerShell Set-Content $PROFILE.AllUsersCurrentHost { # or $PROFILE.AllUsersAllHosts? $WindowsIdentity = [System.Security.Principal.WindowsIdentity]::GetCurrent() $WindowsPrincipal = [System.Security.Principal.WindowsPrincipal]::new($WindowsIdentity) if ($WindowsPrincipal.IsInRole([System.Security.Principal.WindowsBuiltInRole]::Administrator)) { Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy AllSigned -Scope Process } } ``` This would require the user to (re)sign the $Profile when modified. Signing should be limited to a specific "CodeSigners" group and self-signing can only be done with elevated rights. (Other possibilities to achieve the same results might be using a separate user/admin execution policies and/or changing the explorer context menu) This will cause user profiles to be disabled if not signed when running as an elevated administrator: (not sure how this whole issue would apply to other operating systems)

title: Profiles shouldn't unnoticeable shared through UAC

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When querying more counters at once and one of them is [User Input Delay Per Session] counterset, it fails with breaking the perfmon functionality (corrupted/disabled PerfLib, etc...).
It happens in some specific combinations like [User Input Delay Per Session] and [Memory] or [System] countersets. In such combinations invoking Get-Counter will terminate powershell process or returns non-zero Status property for the CounterSamples.
[User Input Delay Per Session] counterset works with .e.g. [SMB Server] counterset so not all are affected.
When two different get-counter cmdlets are invoked ([User Input Delay Per Session] separately), all counters are returned without issues.
Tested on Windows 2019, Powershell 5.1 and 7.2.2, same behavior.

### Expected behavior
When querying array of counters in one "dataset" and [User Input Delay per Session] is used, valid data should be returned without needing to read [User Input Delay per Session] separately.
So this should work:
```console
(Get-Counter -Counter @('\smb server\receive bytes/sec','\memory\page faults/sec','\user input delay per session(max)\max input delay') -SampleInterval 1 -MaxSamples 1).CounterSamples|Select InstanceName,Path,CookedValue,Status
```

### Actual behavior
When querying array of counters in one dataset and [User Input Delay per Session] is used, it starts to return invalid data or terminates powershell completely.
Issuing command:
```console
(Get-Counter -Counter @('\smb server\receive bytes/sec','\memory\page faults/sec','\user input delay per session(max)\max input delay') -SampleInterval 1 -MaxSamples 1).CounterSamples|Select InstanceName,Path,CookedValue,Status
```
Returns error and non-zero STATUS for MEMORY Counters:
```console
Get-Counter: The data in one of the performance counter samples is not valid. View the Status property for each PerformanceCounterSample object to make sure it contains valid data.
InstanceName Path                                                         CookedValue     Status
------------ ----                                                         -----------     ------

             \\ov2p2194\memory\page faults/sec                                      0 3221228472
max          \\ov2p2194\user input delay per session(max)\max input delay           0          0
```

body:
### Steps to reproduce

Previously I've been able to read event logs in user context using `Get-Winevent -FilterHashTable`. For some reason, I don't have permissions to filter the logs with `-FilterHashTable`. This can be tested with the following:

```
#Create Provider: "Test"
New-EventLog -LogName Application -Source "Test" -ErrorAction Ignore

#Create an event under the provider we just created
Write-EventLog -LogName "Application" -Source "Test" -EventID 100 -EntryType Information -Message "This is a test message"

#Filter out the event we just created
Get-WinEvent -ErrorAction Ignore -FilterHashtable @{
    ProviderName = "Test";
    LogName      = "Application";
}
```

When I run the last command as an Administrator however, it works. I can also find the event without `-FilterHashTable` (in user context) :

```
$logs = Get-WinEvent -LogName "Application" -MaxEvents 1000 -ErrorAction Ignore
$logs | Where-Object {$_.ProviderName -eq "Test"}

TimeCreated                     Id LevelDisplayName Message

2022-04-13 09:21:48            100 Information      This is a test message

```

### Steps to reproduce

On a Windows machine with Visual Studio installed:

```pwsh
$vswhere = "${Env:\ProgramFiles(x86)}\Microsoft Visual Studio\Installer\vswhere.exe"
Import-Module "$(& $vswhere -prerelease -latest -property installationPath)\Common7\Tools\Microsoft.VisualStudio.DevShell.dll"

Enter-VsDevShell
```

The `Get-Help Enter-VsDevShell` output is:

```text
NAME
    Enter-VsDevShell

SYNTAX
    Enter-VsDevShell -VsInstallPath <string> [-SkipExistingEnvironmentVariables] [-StartInPath <string>] [-Arch {Default | x86 | amd64 | arm | arm64}] [-HostArch {Default | x86 | amd64}] [-DevCmdArguments
    <string>] [-DevCmdDebugLevel {None | Basic | Detailed | Trace}] [-SkipAutomaticLocation] [-SetDefaultWindowTitle] [-ReportNewInstanceType {PowerShell | Cmd | LaunchScript}] [<CommonParameters>]

    None
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

SCCM cmdlets honour the $VerbosePreference value of the calling scope.
If $VerbosePreference is set to "Continue", passing -Verbose:$false does not disable verbose output.

Workarounds are to put all SCCM cmdlets in their own script blocks, and override $VerbosePreference in each script block.
This introduces its own issues with variable scope.
An alternative is to save and restore the $VerbosePreference, before and after calling each cmdlet,
but this adds extra lines of unwanted code.

The docs for PS indicates that passing -Verbose:$false should disable verbose output, but clearly the SCCM cmdlets are not working in this way. As SCCM is another MS product I figured you wouldn't mind me opening a bug for this here ;)


### Expected behavior

```console
$VerbosePreference = "Continue" # module or script scope
$someCmApp | Move-CMObject -FolderPath \blah\de\blah -Verbose:$false
# no verbose output desired from SCCM cmdlet
```


### Actual behavior

```console
# pages of verbose output
# however...

$VerbosePreference = "Continue" # module or script scope
...
# other work where verbose output is desired
...
& {
  $VerbosePreference = "SilentlyContinue"
  Move-CMObject ...
  # no Verbose output with the nested script block
}
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Don't blindly overwrite commands that are part of a signed script or module.

Reading this [Colibri Loader combines Task Scheduler and PowerShell in clever persistence technique](https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/04/colibri-loader-combines-task-scheduler-and-powershell-in-clever-persistence-technique/), I am quiet surprised to see how easily it appears to overwrite a native (presumably signed) command.

Somehow, I think it should be possible to get the user's attention when this happens by asking whether to overwrite a function that is part of a signed script or module (when the `Set-ExecutionPolicy` is set to `RemoteSigned` or higher?):


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Wishful thinking:

```PowerShell
PS C:\> Get-Content .\MyScript.ps1
function MySigned {
    Write-Host 'Hello World'
}
PS C:\> $Certificate = Get-ChildItem Cert:\LocalMachine\My | Where-Object {$_.Subject -eq 'CN=SelfSigned'}
PS C:\> Set-AuthenticodeSignature -FilePath MyScript.ps1 -Certificate $Certificate

PS C:\> . .\MyScript.ps1
PS C:\> MySigned
Hello World
PS C:\> function MySigned { Write-Host 'Hello Colibri' }
```
At this point I would like see a message in the direction of:

> Do you want to overwrite the command `MySigned` which is a part
> of the signed script `MyScript` from the publisher "SelfSigned"?
>
> [N] No  [Y] Yes [?] Help (default is "N"):

This would probably require that all functions (commands) that are part of a signed script or module should be securely marked as "signed" to be able to check for any possible unwanted overwrites.

**Notes**
* The question should also appear when the (signed) command is overwritten in a higher scope.
* The question should **not** appear when the command comes from the same source (script/module, aka publisher) as the existing command, e.g. in case of a recurse function.

# PR Summary

Removes the usage of `BinaryFormatter` in PSRP connections.

## PR Context

The `BinaryFormatter` class is marked as obsolete and is planned to be removed in a future .NET version https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2020/better-obsoletion/binaryformatter-obsoletion.md. One location where it is used in pwsh is when serializing the client's time zone. On the server end PowerShell has ignored this property since v3 and even on v2 it has an exception handler to ignore invalid values. This means the client can either omit the property altogether or send an empty value and the server will still be fine.

One minor difference between a missing property and an empty property value is that `$PSSenderInfo.ClientTimeZone` is `$null` when it's missing and set to `[TimeZone]::Current` when it's an empty value. So to preserve as much existing behaviour an empty value was used instead.

The only concern I have with this approach that I haven't tested it with an Exchange endpoint to see if it has any special behaviour with this property.

Partially addressed https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/14054

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

It works if done other way around (exported on PS5, imported on PS7).

Seems like at some point Export-PSSession moved to a different assembly. Considering that `VersionOfScriptGenerator` has stayed on 1.0, that seems to imply that generated modules should be backwards compatible. Changing:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/7cc9c874730e87b06dbe54d50e77c1c472996c54/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility/commands/utility/ImplicitRemotingCommands.cs#L2112

to something like the following fixes the issue
```csharp
string versionOfScriptGenerator = "$executionContext.InvokeCommand.GetCommand('Export-PSSession', [System.Management.Automation.CommandTypes]::Cmdlet).ImplementingType::VersionOfScriptGenerator";
```

### Steps to reproduce

On PS7 export remote session to a module:
```powershell
$s =  New-PSSession -ComputerName TestMachine

Export-PSSession -Session $s -CommandName Get-Date -OutputModule $PWD\Remote_GetDate -AllowClobber
```

On PS 5.1 try to load the module
```powershell
Import-Module .\Remote_GetDate
```

### Expected behavior

```console
# Remote_GetDate module loads, can run the implicit remoting command
(Get-Date).PSComputerName
```


### Actual behavior

```console
# Module fails to load
Unable to find type [Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ExportPSSessionCommand,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility, Version=7.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35]
```


### Error details

```console
Unable to find type [Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ExportPSSessionCommand,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility, Version=7.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf38
56ad364e35].
At D:\Dev\Remote_GetDate\Remote_GetDate.psm1:15 char:57
+ ... Generator = [Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ExportPSSessionCommand, Mi ...
+                 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (Microsoft.Power...1bf3856ad364e35:TypeName) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : TypeNotFound

Import-Module : The module cannot be loaded because it has been generated with an incompatible version of the Export-PSSession cmdlet. Generate the module with the Expo
rt-PSSession cmdlet from the current session, and try loading the module again.
At line:1 char:1
+ Import-Module .\Remote_GetDate
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : OperationStopped: (The module cann...e module again.:String) [Import-Module], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : The module cannot be loaded because it has been generated with an incompatible version of the Export-PSSession cmdlet. Generate the modul
   e with the Export-PSSession cmdlet from the current session, and try loading the module again.,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ImportModuleCommand
```


### Environment data

```powershell
# Module exported on
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.3-28-g7cc9c874730e87b06dbe54d50e77c1c472996c54
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When run the first time, this form becomes DPI aware. The proper math will adjust the form to the users monitor scale.
Upon running the second time, the form is DPI aware at the start of the session, meaning $vscreen already returns the monitors height instead of the legacy scale height.

**_Any .Net form presented on the system afterwards will be DPI aware which is not the intent._** 

```
Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms, System.Drawing, presentationframework
$vscreen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen.height

[xml]$xml = @"
            <Window
                    xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation"
                    xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml">
            </Window>
"@
$dum = (New-Object System.Xml.XmlNodeReader $xml)
$win = [Windows.Markup.XamlReader]::Load($dum)

$screen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen.height

$global:ctscale = ($screen/$vscreen)
    
$Form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form
	$Form.Text="Form"
	$Form.Width = 600 * $ctscale
	$Form.Height = 480 * $ctscale
    

	$Button1 = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Button
		$Button1.Text="Button1"
		$Button1.Width=75 * $ctscale
		$Button1.Height=23 * $ctscale
		$Button1.Top=84 * $ctscale
		$Button1.Left=144 * $ctscale
        $Form.Controls.Add($Button1)
		#$Button1.add_Click({[System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox]::Show("Button1 click!","Example Event","OK",64) | Out-Null})
[System.Windows.Forms.Application]::Run($Form) | Out-Null
	#For consecutive forms use $Form.Show() or modal $Form.ShowDialog(). Only use Run once.
```

### Expected behavior

```console
.Net Form DPI awarness from the session should not stick after .Net Form is closed for other .Net Forms.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
.Net Form DPI awarness from the session sticks after .Net Form is closed for other .Net Forms.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Prerequisites

### Steps to reproduce

Problem with .NET forms DPI scaling, not scaling in blurry mode/legacy scaling in 7.2.2
Causes position of controls to skew in unexpected manner. 

In this case, I use a dialog designer that has the same exact problem as the visual studio form designer, so knowing the screen scale is not enough. Also, I do not know a viable method to get the screen scale for other forms other than below, which this problem renders useless.

```
$vscreen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen.height

[xml]$xml = @"
            <Window
                    xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation"
                    xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml">
            </Window>
"@
$dum = (New-Object System.Xml.XmlNodeReader $xml)
$win = [Windows.Markup.XamlReader]::Load($dum)

$screen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen.height

$global:ctscale = ($screen/$vscreen)
```


### Expected behavior

```console
Forms should scale in legacy compatibility, at scale value of 1.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Forms scale at current scale of monitor, similar to WPF, but with control positions skewed.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
I uninstalled this update, needed immediate correction. Can replicate appearance programatically. Before I realized this was update related, I performed a system restore (did not resolve). Had to uninstall Powershell and reinstall to get my system to behave.
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

While working with a rest api of a ITSM system we're using I ran into the issue that I was able to use PowerShell 5.1 to issue GET request via the Invoke-RestMethod cmdlet but when I did the same on PowerShell 7.2.2/7.3.0 the request always seemed to fail with an http 400 error. I did some digging around with Fiddler and I found that the request done with PowerShell 7.2.2 added a Content-Length header to the request.

**Request details when done from PowerShell 5.1:**

```
GET https://api.somesite.com/v1/me HTTP/1.1
Authorization: Bearer xxxxxxx
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT; Windows NT 10.0; nl-NL) WindowsPowerShell/5.1.19041.1320
Content-Type: application/json
Host: api.somesite.com
Connection: Keep-Alive
```

**Request details when done from PowerShell 7.2.2/7.3.0:**

```
GET https://api.somesite.com/v1/me HTTP/1.1
Host: api.somesite.com
Authorization: Bearer xxxxxxx
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044; nl-NL) PowerShell/7.3.0
Content-Type: application/json
Content-Length: 0
```



### Expected behavior

```console
Invoke-RestMethod -Method Get should not add Content-Length header to request
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Invoke-RestMethod -Method Get does add Content-Length header to request
```


### Error details

_No response_

```powershell
Name                           Value
```

# PR Summary

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

This PR implements support for forward slashes in partial network share (UNC paths) names when performing tab completion (Close #17111)

## PR Context

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

This makes tab completion easier to use e.g. when using French layout keyboards, where entering a forward slash (`Shift+:`) is way easier than entering a backslash (`AltGr+8`).
